awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Enhancing the Precision of the Double Chooz Experiment  By Calibration with an Articulated Robotic Arm
awd_abstract_narration:
A new exciting and profound question was brought up by the confirmation of neutrino oscillations: Can the source of the matter/anti-matter asymmetry of the universe be explained by CP violation in the neutrino sector? The answer to this fundamental question strongly depends on the magnitude of observable CP violation effects, which is, restricted by the size of the neutrino oscillation angle theta-13. The PI proposes a combined research and educational project focused on a highly sensitive search for a non-zero value of this neutrino mixing angle with the Double Chooz experiment. This experiment will measure, or significantly improve the upper limit on, the value of sin^2 (2theta-13) from 0.2, as measured by CHOOZ experiment, to 0.026.

The PI proposes to build a multi-axis calibration system that will greatly enhance the precision of the measurement. Precise and comprehensive calibrations are critical to the minimization of systematic errors and the success of the Double Chooz experiment. The development, utilization and optimization of the articulated robotic arm system, and the analysis of the data obtained from the full volume calibration are all part of this five year research and education project. Besides providing an important augmentation for the Double Chooz experiment, the development of an articulated, robotic arm calibration system and its usage will also have important applications to future neutrino experiments where full target volume calibration systems will be of increasing importance. 

The PI is strongly committed to extending the scope of her research program to educate a broad range of students. A highly interactive multimedia web site that will introduce the physics of neutrinos and the Double Chooz experiment to high school students and their teachers as well as interested members of the general public will be designed and developed.

por.por_cntn:
This project was dedicated to the search and measurement of the last unknown  neutrino mixing angle called theta13. Neutrinos are the lightest elementary particles known to exist and they fly nearly at the speed of light. There are three types (flavors)  of neutrino particles. Neutrinos alternate among three different flavors along their flight which is called neutrino oscillations.  The amount of mixing (conversion) among the flavors is measured by the value of the neutrino mixing angle. 

There are three neutrino mixing angles theta12, theta23 and theta13. While theta12 and theta23 are rather large and were already measured by 2002, only the upper limit existed for the angle theta13 until 2011, as it was comparatively very small.  Measurement of the angle theta13 completes the picture of neutrino oscillation phenomenon.

Knowledge of the angle theta13 is also central to the one of the most fundamental open questions in physics today closely related to our own existence: why does matter dominate over anti-matter in our Universe? A promising explanation to this puzzle maybe difference in how neutrinos and their anti-matter counterparts called anti-neutrinos behave, measured by a so-called CP-violation phase angle. However, the CP-violation phase angle is inseparable from the neutrino mixing angle theta13. Thus, knowledge of theta13 is mandatory in testing this promising hypothesis and getting closer to finding the source of matter-antimatter asymmetry.

The Double Chooz experiment is one of the three experiments designed to measure neutrino mixing angle theta13 with high precision. The expected small value of theta13 placed very strong constraints on the allowed systematic error of the experiment to be smaller than 0.5% total, which has been unprecedented in these types of experiments before. The most precise experiment from the previous generation had the overall systematic error of 2.6%.

The Double Chooz determines theta13 by measuring electron anti-neutrino flux coming from the nuclear power plant 1 km away. The Double Chooz experiment consists of two identical detectors. The addition of the second identical detector at 400 m distance from the reactor cores enables comparative flux measurement of the incoming antineutrino flux at two detectors to minimize the systematic error of the measurement.

In the fall of 2011, the Double Chooz was the first experiment ever to publish measurement of theta13 with just one detector and establish with 3σ confidence level (C.L.) that theta13 is not zero. In early 2012, two other experiments Daya Bay and RENO, obtained a similar value for theta13 mixing angle and established its non-zero value with 5σ C.L. In March of 2016, Double Chooz published its first measurement with two detector set-up confirming the measurement with more than 5σ C.L. confirming the discovery of the neutrino mixing angle theta13.

The discovery of theta13 finally completed the neutrino oscillation matrix and reinforced the plans to measure CP-violation phase angle in the next decade.

An important part of reducing the systematic errors in Double Chooz is calibration of the two detectors and their comparision to establish the total detector related systematic error. Several calibration systems have been developed to calibrate Double Chooz. The system designed to calibrate the entire detector target volume of two detectors is called articulated robotic arm (ARA) and has been designed, fabricated, tested and commissioned under this grant. ARA is designed to deploy radioactive sources for calibration purposes about 7 m from the detector access point at the top, in areas impossible to access otherwise.  In order to fulfill calibration goals, the positioning precision is better than 1 cm.
